Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images of 0.5%Pd/ZSM-5 (a), 1%Pd/ZSM-5 (b), and 3%Pd/ZSM-5 (c) catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM images of 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1) (a), 3%Pd-0.7 P/ZSM-5(1) (b), 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5 (1) (c), 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(2) (d), 3%Pd-0.7 P/ZSM-5(2) (e), and 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(2) (f) catalysts. The behavior of palladium-phosphorus catalysts deposited on a Na-ZSM-5 zeolite support, in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide under mild conditions has been studied. It was found that elemental phosphorus exerts a promoting effect on the activity and selectivity of Pd catalysts for synthesizing H2O2. A direct relationship between the P:Pd ratio (in the range P:Pd = 0: 1.0) and the activity of the catalysts is shown. The influence of phosphorus on the properties of palladium catalysts in side reactions: decomposition and hydrogenation of H2O2 is considered. The chemical and phase composition of Pd-P particles was studied by ICP, HRTEM, electron diffraction, and XRD methods. The modifying effect of phosphorus on the properties of Pd catalysts in the direct synthesis of H2O2 is associated with the formation of solid solutions between palladium and phosphorus, an increase in the dispersion, and the surface roughness of Pd-P particles. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Direct synthesis Hydrogen peroxide Palladium Phosphorus Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (Н2О2) ranks among one hundred most important chemicals [1]. It is widely used in various branches of industry as a highly efficient and environmentally benign oxidizer, bleaching and cross-linking agent, disinfectant, and initiator of polymerization reactions. In particular, Н2О2 is used in wastewater purification, the pulp-and-paper and textile industries (for bleaching of paper/cellulose, cotton, and woolen fabrics), electronic components (for etching of semiconductors: germanium and silicon wafers), in the production of synthetic detergents, and the chemical industry (e.g., for the preparation of propylene oxide) [2,3]. The annual consumption of Н2О2 augments by ∼ 3–4%: from 1 million tons in 1970–4.5 million tons in 2010 and 6 million tons in 2020 due to the ever-increasing application of Н2О2 and chlorine-free technologies [2,4]. However, despite the constant growth in production, Н2О2 remains a rather expensive compound (about $500 per ton of 50% Н2О2) [1]. Therefore, developing environmentally friendly methods for synthesizing Н2О2 represents a challenge for ecology and economics. Hydrogen peroxide is usually synthesized by autoxidation of primary or secondary alcohols, for example, isopropanol to H2O2 and acetone, by electrolysis of aqueous solutions of potassium persulfate (К2S2O8) or ammonium salt ((NH4)2S2O8), and by the anthraquinone method [5]. Unfortunately, the autoxidation protocol does not produce H2O2 of high purity due to the solubility of isopropanol in hydrogen peroxide. The electrochemical method permits obtaining a high purity of 30–98% H2O2 solution, but this procedure is very energy-consuming. Therefore, about 98% of H2O2 in the world is obtained by the anthraquinone method. The reaction involves sequential selective Pd (or Ni)-catalyzed hydrogenation of alkylanthraquinone to alkylhydroanthraquinone followed by autoxidation of the latter to hydrogen peroxide and alkylanthraquinone [2,5,6]. Side processes of alkylanthraquinone hydrogenation (catalytic saturation of aromatic rings and hydrogenolysis of alkylhydroanthraquinone C–OH bond) reduce H2O2 selectivity and require periodic replacement of the initial substrate [7,8]. The anthraquinone method is exploited in large-scale production, being unprofitable for small plants. The direct synthesis of H2O2 represents an attractive alternative to the anthraquinone process. This facile method for synthesizing hydrogen peroxide from H2 and O2 is still challenging for the research community [1]. The mixtures of H2 and O2 are explosive in a wide range of compositions (4–94%), and a strong dilution of gases with an inert diluent decreases the yield of H2O2. However, the main obstacle to its industrial application is the low productivity of catalysts and, as a consequence, the insufficient mass concentration of H2O2 in the reaction solution. Thus, the most active in direct synthesis unmodified Pd catalysts have low H2O2 selectivity and high H2O selectivity [1]. The dissociative chemisorption of molecular oxygen on Pd directs the parallel interaction of H2 and O2 toward the formation of not H2O2 but water (Eqs. 1, 2): (1) H 2 + O 2 = H 2 O 2 (2) H 2 + 1 / 2 O 2 = H 2 O From a kinetic point of view, if we compare two parallel reactions (1) and (2), then the formation of H2O2 is more preferable than H2O. In a semibatch reactor, the activation energy of the direct synthesis reaction (EA = 67.0 kJ.mol–1, reaction 1) is almost two times lower than the activation energy of H2O formation (EA = 133.8 kJ.mol–1, reaction 2) [9]. In addition, it must be taken into account that H2O2 is a thermodynamically less stable compound than water and spontaneously decomposes into H2O and O2. Moreover, the standard Gibbs energy of H2O2 decomposition into water and molecular oxygen ( ∆ r G 298 o = −116.8 kJ.mol–1), as well as the Gibbs energy of H2O2 hydrogenation to H2O ( ∆ r G 298 o = −354.0 kJ.mol–1), is significantly less than zero [4,10]. Under normal conditions, the rate of H2O2 decomposition into water and oxygen is low, but direct synthesis catalysts significantly accelerate this process. Therefore, further catalytic decomposition and hydrogenation of H2O2 to water also reduces the yield of hydrogen peroxide (Eqs. 3, 4): (3) H 2 O 2 = H 2 O + 1 / 2 O 2 (4) H 2 O 2 + H 2 = 2 H 2 O The highest H2O2 selectivity will be observed for catalysts on which the chemisorption of the O2 molecule proceeds at a low rate, and the addition of hydrogen to O2 * proceeds at a high rate [11]. Against this background, the strategies for improving Pd catalysts selectivity in direct syntheses are focused on suppressing the dissociative adsorption of the oxygen molecule and Н2О2. This is achieved by the introduction of halide-ions and mineral acids into the reaction mixture [1,12], application of bimetallic Pd alloys with noble [1,13] or non-noble metals [14–16] as catalysts, controlling the size and shape of Pd particles [16–18] and, varying the Pd0:Pdδ+ ratio [1]. However, the use of inorganic acids or halides can cause corrosion of the reactor. At the same time, an increase in the selectivity of bimetallic alloys as catalysts in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide is most often accompanied by the reduction of catalytic activity. Therefore, developing efficient catalysts for the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide with an optimal ratio of activity and selectivity remains a crucial research task. Since the beginning of the XXI century, phosphides and sulfides of transition metals obtained by high-temperature methods have found applications as potential hydroprocessing catalysts [19,20]. In hydroprocessing reactions, transition metal phosphides are usually inferior to metals in activity but possess better stability [21,22]. We have developed a low-temperature method for the preparation of colloidal solutions of Pd-P nanoparticles [23], which showed high efficiency in the hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds [24,25], e.g., in the production of hydrogen peroxide by the anthraquinone method [7]. It is known [26] that the electron-deficient form of Pd is less characterized by the reverse donation of electrons to the π * -orbital of the oxygen, which leads to dissociative adsorption of the O2 molecule. At the same time, the dissociation of the hydrogen molecule, which is required for synthesizing Н2О2, efficiently occurs on Pd0 particles. Therefore, the development of efficient catalysts for the production of peroxide from Н2 and О2 strongly depends on the optimal ratio of two Pd chemical forms on the catalyst surface (Pd0:Pdδ+). Certainly, during the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, a part of Pd can be oxidized to PdO by oxygen. But PdO is again easily reduced by hydrogen to Pd0. Due to the incorporation of phosphorus into the crystal lattice of part of Pd, the ratio of two Pd chemical forms (Pd0:Pdδ+) on the surface can be controlled by varying the P:Pd ratio [27]. With this fact, we have studied for the first time the behavior of phosphorus-modified Pd catalysts in the direct synthesis of Н2О2 and evaluated the role of the phosphorus modifier. Zeolite Na-ZSM-5 was used as a support. According to the reported data [28], it is inappropriate to use Pd catalysts on basic supports (for example, MgO) in the direct synthesis of Н2О2, since they accelerate the decomposition of Н2О2. Higher H2O2 productivity is shown by catalysts on supports with low isoelectric points, such as carbon and SiO2 [28]. However, the Pd-P particles deposited on a carbon support were relatively easily leached into solution during the production of Н2О2 by the anthraquinone method [29]. The high efficiency of Pd-Au catalysts incorporated in the cavities of the H-ZSM-5 zeolite framework [13] or deposited on the outer surface [30], also shows the possibility of using zeolites as a carrier for the direct synthesis of H2O2. 2 Experimental 2.1 General procedures Gases. Electrolytic hydrogen (99.999%, AlfaGas) was purified from oxygen and moisture by passing through the columns filled with a nickel-chromium catalyst and CaA zeolites successively. Argon (99.999%, AlfaGas) and nitrogen (99.999%, AlfaGas) were purified from moisture and oxygen impurities by passing through the columns filled with P2O5, granulated alkali, CaA molecular sieves, a moisture indicator, and copper powder heated to 200 °C successively. For direct synthesis, a mixture of synthetic air (20.9% O2 (99.999%), 79.1% N2 (99.999%, AlfaGas)), and hydrogen (99.999%, AlfaGas) was used. Solvents. Benzene (C6H6, 99.8%, EKOS1), N,N-dimethylformamide (HCON(CH3)2, DMF, 99.9%, EKOS1), ethanol (C2H5OH, 95.0%, Medkhimprom) were additionally purified according to standard procedures [31]. Ethanol was first boiled (3 h) and distilled over sulfanilic acid at 78 °C under atmospheric pressure, then boiled and distilled over calcium oxide [32]. It was stored in a sealed ampoule under an argon atmosphere. Benzene was purified from impurities of sulfur compounds by shaking with sulfuric acid, then washed with water, sodium bicarbonate solution, and water, dried over P2O5, boiled, and distilled over metallic sodium and LiAlH4. Benzene was stored in sealed ampoules in an argon atmosphere. Safety note: benzene is a carcinogen. All work with it must be carried out in a fume hood. If necessary, benzene used as a solvent for white phosphorus can be replaced with toluene. N,N-Dimethylformamide was kept over anhydrous CuSO4 until the formation of a green solution in order to dehydrate and remove amine impurities and was twice distilled in vacuo (8 Torr) at a temperature not exceeding 42 °С. All operations associated with the distillation of solvents were carried out in an argon atmosphere. Н2О2 (30%, reagent grade, Dia-m), deionized water (Н2О, Milli-Q, Millipore, 18.2 MΩ.cm−1 resistivity) and aqueous solutions of HCl (analytical reagent grade, 35%, Vecton) were used without further purification. Reagents and precursors. Pd(acac)2 was synthesized using the method reported in [33], and the resulting yellow powder was recrystallized from acetone. A solution of white phosphorus in benzene was used as the phosphorus modifier. All operations with white phosphorus were performed in argon in a Schlenk flask. Support. Zeolite Na-ZSM-5 (Ishimbay Specialized Chemical Plant of Catalysts, Russia, silicate module SiO2:Al2O3 = 30) was preliminarily calcined in a muffle at 500 °C for 4 h to remove moisture. The phase composition and structure of the zeolite were confirmed by XRD analysis on a Shimadzu Maxima XRD 7000 diffractometer. The X-ray diffractogram in the range of 2θ = 5–80 ° was obtained using a copper anode and a diffracted beam monochromator (U = 40 kV and I = 50 mA). Sample identification was carried out according to the card file of the International Zeolite Association. The surface area and pore volume of the Na-ZSM-5 zeolite were determined by nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis using an ASAP 2010 M instrument (Micromeritics) (Figure A.1, SI). Before analysis, the sample was degassed in vacuum at 280 °C for 4 h. The specific surface area was calculated by the BET method. The total pore volume was calculated from the amount of adsorbed nitrogen close to the saturation pressure. The specific surface area is 340 m2/g, the total pore volume is 0.19 cm3/g, the micropore volume is 0.14 cm3/g, and the average pore diameter is 2.2 nm. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Example 1. 0.5 wt% Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst. Safety note: Hydrogen with air forms an explosive mixture. The formation of catalysts in a hydrogen atmosphere was carried out in a batch reactor using Schlenk technology. Before loading the components of the catalytic system, the reaction vessel was previously evacuated twice and filled with hydrogen. Pd(acac)2 (0.0144 g, 4.73 ×10−5 mol) and Na-ZSM-5 zeolite (1 g) were placed in a flow of hydrogen into a glass temperature-controlled vessel preliminarily evacuated and filled with hydrogen. Next, DMF (50 ml) was added and the mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature. The Pd(acac)2 was reduced with hydrogen upon vigorous stirring for 15–20 min at 80 °С and H2 pressure of 2 atm. The use of the most reactive form of phosphorus in the form of white phosphorus makes it possible to carry out the synthesis of Pd-P particles under mild conditions (T = 80 °C, p(H2) = 2 atm), to control easily the P:Pd ratio in Pd-P particles and to study the effect of P:Pd ratio on catalytic performance. The use of other phosphorus sources for the production of phosphides requires more stringent conditions: PO4 3– (H2, 800 °C), HPO3 2– (H2, 500 °C), H2PO2 – (N2, 200 °C), PH3 (H2, 250 °C) [34], P(Okt)3 [35]. 2.3 Catalytic experiments 2.3.1 Direct synthesis of Н2О2 The direct synthesis of Н2О2 was carried out in a temperature-controlled semi-batch glass reactor under mild conditions upon vigorous stirring with a magnetic stirrer (IKA C-Mag HS7). The experiments were performed in ethanol or with an aqueous solution of inorganic acids. In a typical procedure, a mixed solvent, consisting of ethanol (40 ml) and aqueous HCl solution (10 ml, 28 mmol.L–1), was placed into the reactor, saturated with gases, and a catalyst (2 ×10−5 mol Pd, 0.0851 g; 5 ×10−6 mol Pd, 0.0213 g) was loaded. The gases (air and hydrogen) flow rate (30 ml/min) and the gas volume ratio (H2:O2:N2 = 1:5.7:21.7) were achieved using a gas mixer (SG-2, “NEOSIB” company). The gases were fed into the reactor through a Schott filter (pore size = 100 µm). The reaction was implemented at 10 °C at a gas pressure of 1 atm with samples of the liquid and gas phases taken from time to time. Catalytic experiments were carried out with vigorous stirring at 1200 rpm. The Н2О2 concentration was determined spectrophotometrically (by the absorption band at 407 nm) after the separation of solution from the catalyst through a 0.22 µm syringe filter and the formation of a peroxide complex via the reaction of Н2О2 with TiOSO4 [36]. H 2 O 2 + TiO 2 + + 2 H 2 O = Ti ( O 2 ) ( O H ) ( H 2 O ) 2 + H + The gas phase composition was analyzed on a Chromatec-Crystal 5000 chromatograph (Chromatec, Russia) equipped with a CaA column and a katharometer, according to the internal standard method. Nitrogen was used as an internal standard, and the gas-carrier was argon. Selectivity with respect to Н2О2 and conversion of H2 were calculated by Eq. 4–5: (4) H 2 Conversion % = mol ( min ) − 1 H 2 ( t ( 0 ) − mol ( min ) − 1 H 2 ( t 1 ) mol ( min ) − 1 H 2 ( t ( 0 ) ) × 100 (5) H 2 O 2 Selectivity % = H 2 O 2 detected ( mol ( min ) − 1 ) H 2 consumed ( mol ( min ) − 1 ) × 100 2.3.2 Decomposition of H2O2 under an inert atmosphere The catalytic decomposition of Н2О2 was carried out in a temperature-controlled glass reactor connected to a volumetric system under a nitrogen atmosphere at 10 °C upon intensive stirring with a magnetic stirrer (IKA C-Mag HS7) both in ethanol and with the addition of an aqueous solution of inorganic acids: HCl (10 ml, 28 mmol.L−1). In a typical procedure, a catalyst (2 ×10−5 mol Pd, 0.0851 g), ethanol (30 ml), and 1.9 ml of 4 M H2O2 were placed into a reaction vessel, evacuated and filled with nitrogen, and closed with a Teflon cap with a silicon rubber seal. The concentration of H2O2 for hydrogenation and decomposition of H2O2 in the rection vessel was the same: 1 wt%. The reaction was monitored by taking samples of 1 ml. The solution was filtered from the catalyst through a 0.22 µm syringe filter, and the concentration of Н2О2 was determined spectrophotometrically (see section “Direct synthesis of Н2О2”). The reaction vessel was covered with an opaque cloth to prevent the photochemical decomposition of hydrogen peroxide. The experiments with the addition of acid inhibitors were performed similarly. 2.3.3 Hydrogenation of H2O2 Hydrogenation of Н2О2 was carried out in a glass temperature-controlled vessel at 10 °C upon vigorous stirring under a hydrogen atmosphere, maintaining a constant pressure of H2. The experiments were performed in a neutral medium (ethanol) or with the addition of an aqueous solution of inorganic acids: HCl (10 ml, 28 mmol.L−1). In the former case, a catalyst (2 ×10−5 mol Pd, 0.0851 g), ethanol (30 ml), and 1.9 ml of 4 M Н2О2 were placed into the reaction vessel in a hydrogen flow, and the vessel was closed with a Teflon cap with a silicon rubber seal. The reaction was monitored by taking samples of 1 ml. The solution was filtered from the catalyst through a 0.22 µm syringe filter, and the concentration of Н2О2 was determined spectrophotometrically (see section “Direct synthesis of Н2О2”). The experiments with the addition of acid inhibitors were performed similarly. 2.4 Characterization techniques The gas chromatography analysis of the gas mixtures was performed on a Chromatec-Crystal 5000 chromatograph equipped with a CaA column that was 3 m long and a katharometer according to the internal standard method under isothermal conditions: 100 °C (7 min). The gas-carrier (argon) pressure was 10 kPa. The ICP analysis of the catalysts was performed on a high-resolution mass spectrometer (Finnigan MAT, model ELEMENT 2, Germany) after the preliminary decomposition of the samples with nitric acid. To calculate the concentrations, the calibration according to certified solutions CLMS-1–4 (SPEX, USA) with element concentrations of 0.1, 1.0, and 5.0 ng/ml with drift control by internal standard (103Rh) was carried out. A Meinhard concentric low-flow nebulizer (0.1 ml/min) was used to convert the analyzed solution into an aerosol. Detection limits (DL) were evaluated according to the 3σ criterion: DL= Сconc. + 3σ, where Сconc is the average value of the control experiment, σ is the standard deviation of its measurement according to the data obtained for the control samples. The DL values obtained for solutions were recalculated to the content in the initial solution, taking into account the dilution factor. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a Tecnai G2 electron microscope (FEI, USA) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. A drop of the suspension was applied on a carbon-coated copper grid (200 mesh) and dried at room temperature in a box under an inert atmosphere. Images were recorded using a CCD camera (Soft Imaging System, Germany). A TEM image area containing at least 100–200 Pd particles was processed to determine the average size. The surface average diameter (ds) is calculated by the formula: d s = ∑ i n i d i 3 ∑ i n i d i 2 The dispersion (D) is calculated by the formula: D , % = 6 M Pd ρ Pd × d s × A Pd × N A 100 where APd is the area of one surface Pd atom (m2/atom), which is found based on the surface density of Pd (1.2 ×1019 atom/m2) [37], NA is the Avogadro number, ρ is the density of Pd (12.02 g/cm3). The phase composition of the catalysts was determined using X-ray powder diffraction analysis on XRD-D8 ADVANCE (Bruker, Germany) (CuKα radiation, Ni filter, λ = 1.5418 Å). The Pd catalyst particles’ crystalline domain size (CDS) was calculated using the Scherrer formula A.1 (SI). 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Elemental analysis The mass content of palladium and phosphorus in the catalysts was determined by ICP analysis. According to ICP data, the weight content of palladium and phosphorus in the catalysts is close to the initial values of the Pd precursor and elemental phosphorus ( Table 1). 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction analysis The X-ray diffraction patterns of the catalysts are shown in Figures A.2–A.7 (SI). The X-ray diffraction patterns of all Pd-P catalysts contain, apart from reflections of Na-ZSM-5 zeolite, only one broadened peak in the region of reflection angles, 2θ = 35–45°. The gravity center of this reflection coincides with the interplanar distance Pd(111). In the same region, the most intense reflections of Pd-enriched phosphides are observed (Pd6P, Pd3P, Pd5P2, etc.). Fig. 1 shows a narrow region of three X-ray diffraction patterns of Pd catalysts (3%Pd/ZSM-5, 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1), and 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(2)) and Na-ZSM-5 zeolite. Despite the close mass content of Pd in these three samples, the peak intensities with maxima in region 2θ = 40° for Pd-P catalysts are much lower, and the half-width is larger than that of the 3%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst. In this case, regardless of the deposition method, at a higher P:Pd ratio, a significant broadening of the Pd(111) peak is detected in the X-ray diffraction patterns of the catalysts (Fig. 1). In the X-ray diffraction patterns of the 3%Pd-1.0Р/ZSM-5(1) and 3%Pd-1.0Р/ZSM-5(2) catalysts, a peak at 40° is absent (Figs. A.5, A.7, SI). The broadening of the peaks, observed in the diffraction pattern, can be caused by the small size of Pd particles (<100 nm) and/or the structure disorder due to chemical inhomogeneity. If the particle size is smaller than 3 nm, the samples may become X-ray amorphous [38]. Since the particle size of these catalysts is greater than 3 nm (TEM data, (see Section 2.3.3), it can be assumed that a disordered solid solution of phosphorus in palladium is formed and 3%Pd-1.0Р/ZSM-5(1) and 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(2) samples have quasi-amorphous structure. Five-fold exposure of a narrow region of the reflection angles 2θ (38–42°) of the 3%Pd-0.3Р/ZSM-5(2) catalyst gives additional information about its phase composition. In the X-ray diffraction pattern of the sample, against the background of the broad Pd(111) peak, low-intensity reflections with d/n = 2.328 Å, 2.259 Å, and 2.237 Å are observed. The peak maxima (d/n = 2.328 Å and 2.237 Å) coincide both with the interplanar distances of the Pd3P0.95 phosphide (d/n = 2.324 Å (220), 2.2387 Å (031) # 089–3046) and with low-intensity peaks of the Na-ZSM-5 support (Fig. A.8, SI). But the ratio of the intensities of the two reflections with d/n = 2.237 Å and 2.302 Å in the X-ray diffraction pattern of the Pd-0.3Р/ZSM-5(2) catalyst is different. This fact indicates an overlap of 2.237 Å bands of Na-ZSM-5 zeolite and Pd3P0.95 phosphide and evidences the presence of individual crystalline particles of Pd3P0.95 and Pd5P2 (d/n = 2.288 Å, I/I0 = 100, # 00–019–0887). Even after calcining the Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst in an argon atmosphere for 4 h at 400 °C, the identification of its phase composition is difficult due to the weak distinguishability of the diffraction pattern. The absence of a diffraction pattern with clearly distinguishable peaks indicates an admixture of an amorphous component (Fig. A.9, SI). The presence of an asymmetric peak in the region of 40° may be due to a structural defect or uneven distribution of components in the particles of alloys or solid solutions [39]. The individual reflections observed in the region of diffraction angles of 40° on the X-ray diffraction pattern of the Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst can presumably be attributed to the Pd3P0.95, Pd3P, Pd3P0.8, and Pd6P phosphides (Fig. A.9, SI). A clearer diffraction pattern was obtained for the Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1) sample after it was calcined at 400 °C for 4 h in an argon atmosphere (Fig. A.10, SI). All three peaks in the region of diffraction angles of 40° (d/n = 2.32 Å, 2.26 Å, 2.23 Å) correspond to palladium phosphide Pd3P (d/n = 2.3290 Å (220), 2.2589 Å (112), 2.2369 (031) # 065–2415). Thus, according to XRD data, phosphorus-modified catalysts represent mainly solid phosphorus solutions in palladium with various P:Pd ratios. Some particles are contained in the catalyst samples as crystalline phosphides. The method of obtaining Pd-P catalysts and the initial P:Pd ratio affect the structural ordering of the particles (Table 1). 3.1.3 Transmission electron microscopy TEM images of unmodified catalysts with different weight content of Pd (Pd/ZSM-5) are shown in Fig. 2. On TEM images of unmodified catalysts, high-contrast Pd particles are presented as aggregates or aggregated chains, located on the zeolite’s outer surface. The number average (da) and surface average (ds) diameters calculated from TEM images are given in Table 1. The particle size distribution indicates a high polydispersity of the unmodified catalysts. Pd particles’ minimum and maximum sizes differ by 4–7 times. For example, the Pd particle size in the 3%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst varies from 30 to 120 nm, in the 1.0%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst, it changes from 7 to 52 nm, while in the 0.5%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst it ranges 7.4–48.7 nm. When the mass content of Pd increases from 0.5% (Pd/ZSM-5) to 1% (Pd/ZSM-5) and 3% (Pd/ZSM-5), the dispersity decreases by a factor of 2.4, and the number average diameter augments from 26.2 ± 8.7 nm to 34.2 ± 13.7 nm, and 63.2 ± 18.2 nm, respectively (Table 1). TEM images of Pd-P catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 and A.11 (SI). High-contrast Pd-P particles are also located on the support surface. Regardless of the deposition method, modification by phosphorus at the stage of catalyst formation reduces the average size of high-contrast particles to 9.2–12.1 nm and the degree of polydispersity. In particular, the sizes of Pd-P particles in the 3%Pd-0.3Р/ZSM-5(1) catalyst vary from 4.2 to 14.3 nm; in the 3%Pd-0.7Р/ZSM-5(1) catalyst, it changes 6.2–17.3 nm, while in the 3%Pd-1.0Р/ZSM-5(1) catalyst, it ranges 5.2–15.2 nm and the degree of monodispersity is 20.0%, 20.8%, and 18.8%, respectively. Varying the P:Pd ratio from 0.3 to 1.0 has virtually no effect on the average particle size of the 3%Pd-P/ZSM-5(1) catalysts. The average size is equal to 9.2 ± 1.8 nm (3%Pd-0.3Р/ZSM-5(1)), 10.5 ± 2.4 nm (3%Pd-0.7Р/ZSM-5(1)), and 9.6 ± 1.9 nm (3%Pd-1.0Р/ZSM-5(1)). According to TEM data, the particle sizes of the 3%Pd-P/ZSM-5(1) and 3%Pd-P/ZSM-5(2) catalysts differ slightly. The particle sizes of the 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(2) catalyst vary from 5.1 to 19.2 nm, those in the 3%Pd-0.7 P/ZSM-5(2) catalyst change from 2.5 to 15 nm, and in the 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(2) catalyst, they range 4.2–14.4 nm (Fig. 3) and the degree of monodispersity is 24.4%, 49%, and 29%, respectively. It should be noted that for the 3%Pd-0.7Р/ZSM-5(2) catalyst, two types of particles are observed: large (10–11 nm) and small (2–3 nm), the latter being responsible for the high polydispersity of this catalyst. The bimodal particle size distribution in the 3%Pd-0.7 P/ZSM-5(2) catalyst unambiguously evidences that a probable mechanism of Pd-P particle growth involves coalescence [40]. The average particle size slightly decreases at higher P:Pd ratio: from 12.1 ± 2.9 nm (P:Pd = 0.3) to 9.8 ± 4.8 nm (P:Pd = 0.7), and 9.4 ± 2.6 nm (P:Pd = 1.0). The particle size and degree of polydispersity of the Pd-P/ZSM-5(2) catalysts are comparable with those of the Pd-P/ZSM-5(1) catalysts synthesized by the first method. Still, they are smaller than the values of the unmodified Pd catalysts. The microstructure of Pd-P particles was evaluated by high-resolution-TEM (HRTEM). It should be noted that for some particles of Pd-P catalysts obtained by the first method, HRTEM images display interplanar distances of 2.28 Å, 2.36 Å, 2.38 Å, 2.42 Å ( Figs. 4, 5). They correspond to palladium phosphides Pd5P2 (d/n = 2.288 Å, I/Io = 100, d/n = 2.44 Å, I/Io = 30, # 00–019–0887), Pd3P0.8 (d/n = 2.3649 Å, I/Io = 50, hkl 211, # 00–042–0922) and Pd3P0.95 (d/n = 2.37072 Å (102), I/I0 = 66.5, # 00–089–3046). For individual particles of the Pd-0.3Р/ZSM-5(2) catalyst, interplanar distances of 2.32 Å and 2.40 Å are also observed, which correspond to Pd3P0.95 (hkl 220, d/n = 2.324 Å, I/I0 = 74.5, # 00–089–3046) and Pd5P2 phosphides (d/n = 2.44 Å, I/I0 = 30, d/n = 2.288 Å, I/I0 = 100; # 00–019–0887). At the same time, the HRTEM data indicate a low structural ordering of the 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1), 3%Pd-0.7 P/ZSM-5(2), and 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(2) catalysts. The catalyst samples obtained at P:Pd = 1 (3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1), 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(2)) look quasi-amorphous at high magnification (Figs. 4–5). For most of the particles of these catalysts, structural ordering is either absent or manifests at a distance of no more than 1.5 nm. The electron diffraction data also evidences a distortion of the Pd crystal cell due to the incorporation of phosphorus. Also, with an increase in the P:Pd ratio, the structural ordering of the catalyst particles reduces. In particular, the diffraction maxima on the electron diffraction profile of the 3%Pd-0.3Р/ZSM-5(1) catalyst (d/n = 2.286, 2.00, 1.389, 1.200, and 0.90 Å) are close to each other, but slightly exceed the interplanar distances of Pd (d/n = 2.245 Å, I/Io = 100 (111); d/n = 1.94511 Å, I/Io = 60 (200); d/n = 1.37537 Å, I/Io = 42 (220); d/n = 1.17295 Å, I/Io = 55 (311); d/n = 0.892475 Å, I/Io = 40 (331) (# 00–046–1043)) (Figs. A.12–A.14, SI). A similar dependence is observed for the 3%Pd-0.7 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst (Fig. A.13b, SI). At a ratio of P:Pd = 1.0, the diffraction maxima are absent on the electron diffraction profile of the 3%Pd-1.0Р/ZSM-5(1) catalyst (Fig. A.13c, SI). In contrast to the Pd-P catalysts prepared by the first method (Pd-P/ZSM-5(1)), all Pd-P/ZSM-5(2) catalysts exhibit diffuse Debye rings (Fig. A.14, SI). Thus, the results of electron diffraction, HRTEM, and X-ray powder diffraction analysis indicate the formation of a solid solution between palladium and phosphorus and a decrease in the structural ordering of catalyst particles at a higher P:Pd ratio. 3.2 Direct synthesis of Н 2 О 2 from Н 2 and О 2 All samples of Pd and Pd-P catalysts were tested in the direct synthesis of Н2О2, which was implemented in a temperature-controlled semi-batch glass reactor under mild conditions (10 °C, 1 atm) in a neutral medium (ethanol) or with the addition of an aqueous solution of inorganic acids. Without an acid inhibitor and in the presence of unmodified Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts, the Н2О2 concentration in the reaction system was below the detection limit for 2 h (data of UV spectroscopy). Therefore, further experiments were carried out with HCl additives. Preliminarily, for carrying out the reaction in the kinetic region, using the example of Pd-P catalysts, their optimal amount (5 ×10−6 mol Pd) was chosen (Fig. A.15, SI). However, in the case of the unmodified catalyst, 3%Pd/ZSM-5, even in the presence of an acid inhibitor (HCl), the concentration of Н2О2 after 3 h reached only 0.2 × 10−3 mmol.L−1. The activity of 1%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst in the synthesis of Н2О2 was very low and did not exceed 0.1 molН2О2 (kgPd h)−1 and the hydrogen conversion was 2%. Therefore, the effect of the mass content of Pd in unmodified Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts on their properties in the direct synthesis of Н2О2 in the presence of an acid inhibitor was studied under different conditions. Since unmodified Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts are 4–5 times inferior to Pd-P catalysts in terms of dispersion, the experiments were performed at a higher loading of Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts (2 ×10−5 mol Pd). A 4-fold increase in the catalyst load increased Н2О2 concentration to 5 mmol.L−1, while the hydrogen conversion reached 10–12% ( Fig. 6a). The mass content of Pd in unmodified Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts affects their activity to a greater extent than selectivity (Fig. 6). In the absence of a phosphorus modifier, the 1%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst showed the highest activity (80 molН2О2 (kgPd h)−1) in the synthesis of Н2О2, while the 3%Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts turned out to be the least active (50 molН2О2 (kgPd h)−1). The activity of the 0.5%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst (60 molН2О2(kgPd h)−1)) is only 20% higher than that of the 3%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst, despite their twofold difference in dispersity. The selectivity of the Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts relative to Н2О2 is 23–28% (Fig. 6b). Comparison with the literature data shows that the productivity of various Pd catalysts, including those modified with phosphorus, in the direct synthesis of Н2О2 under mild conditions most often varies from 60 to 170 mol Н2О2 (kgPd h)−1, while selectivity ranges 3–66% (Table A.1, SI). Since the zeolite Na-ZSM-5 may have some basicity, direct synthesis of Н2О2 was additionally carried out in the presence of a mechanical mixture of Na-ZSM-5 zeolite and Pd/Na-ZSM-5 catalyst. The proximity of the kinetic curves of H2O2 formation under the action of the Pd/Na-ZSM-5 catalyst and the mechanical mixture: Na-ZSM-5 zeolite - Pd/Na-ZSM-5 catalyst minimizes the influence of the support on the H2O2 yield (Fig. A.16, SI). To establish the modifying effect of phosphorus on the properties of catalysts in the direct synthesis of Н2О2 and to select the optimal conditions of the process, the P:Pd ratio, the mass content of Pd, and the method of depositing Pd-P particles were varied. The use of a mechanical mixture of Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst and P/ZSM-5 in the direct synthesis of H2O2 did not affect the properties of the Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst (Fig. A.17, SI). At the same time, the introduction of phosphorus into the reaction system at the stage of Pd catalyst formation changes their properties. Unlike unmodified catalysts, in the presence of 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1), Н2О2 was formed even without an acid inhibitor. The concentration of hydrogen peroxide under these conditions reached 0.8 mmol/l, and this value increased by order of magnitude in the presence of an acid inhibitor ( Fig. 7). The average activity of 3%Pd-nP/ZSM-5(1) catalysts, calculated over 30 min, varies from 200 to 340 molН2О2 (kgPd h)−1, while that of 3%Pd-nP/ZSM-5(2) changes from 230 to 280 molН2О2 (kgPd h)−1 ( Fig. 8). At close sizes of Pd–P particles, the increase in the P:Pd ratio from 0.3 to 1.0 enhances the activity of 3%Pd–nP/ZSM-5(1) catalysts by a factor of 1.7. At the same time, a decrease in the mass content of Pd in the Pd-nP/ZSM-5(1) catalyst from 3% to 0.5%Pd results in a 2-fold drop in the yield of hydrogen peroxide (Fig. A.18, SI). The selectivity of the reaction with respect to Н2О2 under the action of 3%Pd-nP/ZSM-5(1) catalysts also increases from 23% to 28% (n = 0) to 38% (n = 0.3) and 45–48% (n = 0.7, 1.0) (Figs. 6–7). Among all the catalysts studied, 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1) shows the optimal ratio of activity and selectivity. The activity of 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1) exceeds that of the best unmodified catalyst (1%Pd/ZSM-5) by 4.5 times (Fig. 8), and its selectivity is 20% higher. An increase in H2O2 selectivity under the action of Pd-P catalysts indicates a smaller contribution of side reactions. Comparison of the 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst properties with published data is difficult due to size sensitivity and different reaction conditions. It can be noted that the productivity (P) under mild conditions of the 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst is superior to such catalysts as Pd/XC-72 (dPd = 4.7 nm, P = 129 mol kg−1 h−1; S = 74%; modifier – 28 mM HCl) [41], Pd2Sn/TiO2 (dPd = 13.4 nm, P = 60.8 mol kg−1 h−1; S = 80.7%, P = 100 bar), 1%Pd/AC (d = 5.4 nm, P = 62 mol kg−1 h−1, S = 66%, modifier – 1 ml 10 wt% H2SO4, 1 ml 0.1 mol L−1 KBr) [42], 1%Pd-5%Ce/AC (d = 3.2 nm, P = 89 mol kg−1 h−1, S = 69%, modifier – 1 ml 10 wt% H2SO4, 1 ml 0.1 mol L−1 KBr) [42]. More complete information is presented in the table (Table A.1, lines 12–20, SI). However, the selectivity of 3%Pd-nP/ZSM-5 catalysts is still lower than that of some known analogs. It is known [43] that surface phosphides are easily oxidized in air to oxides, and Pd from supported Pd catalysts under conditions of direct synthesis leaches out into an aqueous solution of inorganic acids [12]. In this regard, the question naturally arises about the stability of Pd-P catalysts under conditions of H2O2 direct synthesis and leaching of Pd and P (in the form of oxidized forms) into the solution. Longer direct synthesis experiments under the action of 3%Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst showed that a continuous increase in the H2O2 concentration was observed for 5 h (Fig. A.19, SI). According to the ICP data, 24.1% and 47.3% of Pd, respectively, went into solution after 3 and 11 h from the start of the reaction. Along with Pd, phosphorus is also leached. The degree of catalyst leaching into the solution is commensurate with individual representatives of unmodified Pd catalysts, for example, 3%Pd/hydroxyapatite [44]. The leaching of Pd during direct synthesis can lead to a change in the catalysis nature, and the gas atmosphere in the reactor can change the nature of Pd-P particles. As follows from Fig. A.19, SI, during the long-term direct synthesis of Н2О2, a pronounced inflection was observed on the kinetic curve after 6 h of the experiment. The change in the slope of the kinetic curve may be due to an increase in the rate of H2O2 decomposition with an increase in its concentration and/or partial deactivation (change in nature) of the catalyst. To discriminate hypotheses about the heterogeneous or homogeneous nature of catalysis, the composition of the Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst was studied after a catalytic experiment (direct synthesis of H2O2) for 6 h (symbol Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1)* ), and the filtrate was tested in direct synthesis. The content of Pd and P in the Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1)* sample, according to ICP data, is 1.20% and 0.12%, respectively. This corresponds to a P:Pd molar ratio of 2.91 (gross formula Pd3P1.03). The TEM images of the Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1)* sample show high-contrast particles with an average size of 9.3 ± 4.8 nm (Fig. A.20, SI). The appearance of high-resolution TEM images indicates a poor structural order (Fig. A.21, SI). Some interplanar distances (2.378 Å) correspond to palladium phosphide Pd3P0.95: d/n = 2.37072 Å (102), # 089–306 (Fig. A.21, SI). Thus, after 6 h of operation in the direct synthesis of H2O2, palladium in the catalyst remains in the form of Pd-P particles, despite its partial leaching. These results are consistent with the literature data [45]. The authors [45] showed that the Pd3P/SiO2 catalyst after the Wacker-Tsuji-Oxidation of styrene for 6 h at 50 °C in the Н2О – СН3СООН medium using H2O2 as the oxidant remained in the form of Pd3P, although 65% Pd was leached. According to the reported data [46], palladium phosphides are also relatively stable in a hydrogen atmosphere: H2 does not react with P in Pd phosphides to form PH3. The transparent colorless solution remaining after filtering off the Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1)* catalyst was tested in the direct synthesis of H2O2. During the 3 h of the catalytic experiment, the change in the concentration of H2O2 was within the error of determination, that is, the contribution of leached palladium to the direct synthesis of H2O2 is minimal (Fig. A.22, SI). According to TEM data, there are no Pd-containing nanoparticles in the solution. The data obtained indicate that the direct synthesis of Н2О2 proceeds on the surface of the Pd-1.0 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst. 4 Discussion It has been found that the modification of Pd catalysts with phosphorus at the stage of their synthesis has a promoting effect on the activity and selectivity in the direct synthesis of Н2О2 (Fig. 8). Three reactions usually explain the decrease in the yield of hydrogen peroxide during direct synthesis: the formation of water from H2 and O2 (Eq. 2), catalytic decomposition, and hydrogenation of hydrogen peroxide (Eqs. 3, 4) [1]. Indeed, the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide under the action of the Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts in a nitrogen atmosphere in a neutral medium (ethanol) proceeds at a high rate in a pseudo-first-order reaction (Fig. A.23, SI). The Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts’ activity in the decomposition of Н2О2 drastically increased at lower mass content of Pd ( Table 2). Even with a sufficiently large Pd particle size of 0.5%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst (25 nm), this activity reached 13,000 molН2О2 kgPd −1 h−1 (in nitrogen) and 3500 molН2О2 kgPd −1 (in hydrogen). On the one hand, an increase in the activity of unmodified Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts in the decomposition of Н2О2 in nitrogen at lower mass content of Pd can be due to a change in the dispersity of the catalysts (Table 1). However, the increase in catalytic activity cannot be explained only by the higher dispersity of the catalysts since the reaction turnover frequency (TOF) calculated for surface Pd atoms does not remain constant but depends on the particle size. In particular, the TOF of Н2О2 decomposition under the action of a 0.5%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst (TOF = 690 min−1) is 1.7 times higher than that of 1.0%Pd/ZSM-5 (TOF = 390 min−1) and 6.9 times higher than for 3.0%Pd/ZSM-5 (TOF = 100 min−1). The true TOF of the reaction should not depend on the catalyst particle size. A change in the active sites’ number or reactivity explains TOF’s dependence on the Pd particle size. When the diameter changes from 26 nm to 34 nm, a particle’s total number of Pd atoms increases from 49,043 to 312,669. At the same time, the content of surface Pd atoms diminishes from 11.75% to 3.0%. At smaller particle sizes, the amount of edge and vertex Pd atoms in polyhedra increases, while the number of face atoms, on the contrary, decreases. The observed positive size effect indicates a high reactivity of Pd0 atoms located on the edges and vertices of the polyhedra in Н2О2 dismutation. This result agrees with the existing ideas about the higher activity of coordinatively unsaturated Pd atoms in the decomposition of Н2О2 [47]. Size sensitivity complicates the already difficult task of developing efficient catalysts for the direct synthesis of H2O2. Since not only the experiment conditions and the catalyst nature, but the size and shape of the particles of the active component ambiguously affect the main and side reactions. The activation enthalpy (ΔH⧧) of the H2O2 formation from H2 and O2 is practically independent of the Pd particle size in the range of 0.7–7 nm [11]. Hydrogenation of Н2О2 efficiently proceeds on the faces of Pd(111) crystallites, therefore, as the particle size decreases, the rate and contribution of this side process should decrease. However, with an increase in the catalyst dispersion, the proportion of coordinatively unsaturated atoms on the edges and at the vertices of the polyhedra increases. An increase in the number of coordinatively unsaturated Pd atoms on the edges and at the vertices of the polyhedra favors the H2O2 decomposition reaction [44,48]. The size of Pd crystallites has a similar effect on the third side reaction, the formation of H2O from H2 and O2. This is evidenced by an increase in the activation energy of the reaction with the growth of Pd crystallites [11]. Single Pd atoms are unable to activate H2 and are inactive in the direct synthesis of H2O2 [44]. On the one hand, to improve the productivity of Н2О2 synthesis, it is necessary to increase the dispersity of the catalysts. However, with a smaller size of the catalyst particles, the side process, namely the decomposition of Н2О2, is accelerated as well as H2O formation from H2 and O2. The addition of even small amounts of a phosphorus modifier (P4) at the stage of the synthesis of Pd catalysts has a significant inhibitory effect on the rate of Н2О2 decomposition in nitrogen, even in the absence of acid inhibitors. Under the action of Pd-nP/ZSM-5(1) catalysts, the rate of Н2О2 decomposition decreases by 17–29 times in comparison with 0.5%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst, which is closest to them in terms of dispersity (Table 2, lines 4, 5, 7, 8). A similar dependence is observed for Pd-nP/ZSM-5(2) catalysts obtained by depositing Pd-P particles. Properties of Pd-nP/ZSM-5(1) and Pd-nP/ZSM-5(2) catalysts at P:Pd = 0.7; 1.0 in the decomposition of Н2О2 in a neutral medium are similar. The greatest differences are observed for the catalysts obtained at P:Pd = 0.3. In terms of activity in Н2О2 decomposition activity, Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(2) catalyst is almost by four time superior to the Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1) (Table 2, lines 5, 10). The reasons for the modifying action of phosphorus can be different. At first glance, it can be assumed that in the reaction medium phosphoric acid is formed via the hydrolytic oxidation of phosphorus with traces of oxygen and water. This acid is a good inhibitor of Н2О2 decomposition. However, the addition of an even equimolar amount of phosphoric acid to 0.5%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst did not give the same result achieved with the 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst (Fig. A.24, SI). According to the data of XRD, electron diffraction, and HRTEM, Pd-P catalysts represent solid phosphorus solutions in palladium. However, some particles are contained as crystalline palladium phosphides (see Section 3.1.2). Incorporating phosphorus into the crystal lattice of Pd increases the imperfection of the structure. In this case, the imperfection of the structural ordering depends on the P:Pd ratio and the catalyst preparation method. For example, at the same P:Pd ratio, the difference between the CDS values (a region of defect-free structure) and the average particle size of two catalysts, 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1) (25%) and 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(2) (50%), becomes twofold (Table 1). The crystalline surface of Na-ZSM-5 zeolite favors the formation of more structurally ordered Pd-P particles in the 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst. Due to the greater imperfection of Pd-P particles in the 3%Pd-P/ZSM-5(2) catalyst and to the increase in the number of coordinatively unsaturated Pd atoms, the activity of this catalyst in decomposition Н2О2 exceeds that of the 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1) catalyst. At a ratio of P:Pd > 0.3, both the structural ordering of Pd–P particles and the activity of Pd–P catalysts in the decomposition of Н2О2 decrease. At first glance, this fact contradicts the above hypothesis. However, our previous X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study has shown that the surface of Pd-P particles in a colloidal solution contains two chemical forms of Pd (Pd0, Pdδ+), and three chemical forms of phosphorus (Рδ-, Н2PO4 −, Н2PO3 −) [27] (Fig. A.25, SI). The surface concentration of oxidized forms of phosphorus (Н2PO4 −, Н2PO3 −) increases at a higher P:Pd ratio. The adsorption of phosphate- and phosphite-ions on surface coordinatively unsaturated Pd atoms, competing with Н2О2 molecules, inhibits the decomposition of Н2О2 at a high content of phosphorus in the catalyst in a neutral medium. However, the reverse is true for “hydrogenation” in a neutral medium. 3%Pd-nP/ZSM-5(1) catalysts were more active, and 3%Pd-nP/ZSM-5(2) were less active in Н2О2 “hydrogenation” than unmodified catalysts (Table 2). Depending on the nature of the catalyst, the conversion of Н2О2 in hydrogen can be described by three particular cases: (1) the specific activity of Н2О2 conversion in hydrogen is higher, (2) lower than in a nitrogen atmosphere; and (3) the specific activities of Н2О2 conversion in hydrogen and nitrogen are close (Table 2). The first case is characteristic of the Pd-nP/ZSM-5(1) catalyst (Table 2, lines 5, 7–8). This is quite predictable, given that the total rate of the Н2О2 concentration decrease, under the conditions of hydrogenation catalysis, includes both the rates of hydrogenation and decomposition of Н2О2. At the same time, it can be noted that the Pd-nP/ZSM-5(1) catalysts are highly active in Н2О2 hydrogenation. The second case (a decrease in Н2О2 decomposition rate in a hydrogen atmosphere compared to nitrogen) was observed mainly for unmodified 0.5% and 1% Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts (Table 2, lines 1, 4). On a formal level, it can be said that the rate of Н2О2 decomposition decreases in a hydrogen atmosphere. The Pd-nP/ZSM-5(2) catalysts occupy an intermediate position (Table 2, lines 10, 11, 13). The decrease of Н2О2 decomposition rate in hydrogen under the action of unmodified catalysts may be due to the change in the nature of the catalyst particles. At the temperature of direct synthesis of Н2О2 (Т = 10 °C) and the ratio of H2/O2 > 1, Pd exists in the form of α- and β-hydride phases. According to quantum chemical calculations [10], surface hydrogen facilitates Н2О2 desorption (unlike pure Pd), thus reducing the rate of the side decomposition of Н2О2. Pd-P particles are less prone to forming palladium hydride phases owing to the occupation of vacancies by phosphorus. This fact could explain the different behavior of phosphorus-modified catalysts and unmodified catalysts. However, it should be emphasized that there is a clear-cut distinction in the properties of 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1) and 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(2) catalysts, obtained by two methods, in the decomposition and hydrogenation of Н2О2 in a neutral medium. The former catalyst is most active in “hydrogenation”, while the latter is more active in decomposing Н2О2 (Table 2, lines 5, 10). 3%The Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(1) and 3%Pd-0.3 P/ZSM-5(2) catalysts have similar elemental compositions and particle sizes but differ in structural ordering. This indicates that the roughness of the catalyst particle surface favors the decomposition of Н2О2 and the crystallinity promotes the hydrogenation of Н2О2. The acid inhibitor (HCl) considerably changes the properties of Pd and Pd-P catalysts in the side reactions. It significantly suppresses the rate of Н2О2 decomposition in a nitrogen atmosphere under the action of an unmodified 1%Pd/ZSM-5 catalyst but affects Н2О2 “hydrogenation” to a lesser extent. The decomposition rate decreases by 13 times, and that of “hydrogenation” reduces by 2.4 times (Table 2, lines 2, 3). A different pattern is typical for Pd-P catalysts. The addition of HCl has an inhibitory effect only on the properties of P-modified catalysts during the decomposition of Н2О2 in a nitrogen atmosphere. But if in a nitrogen atmosphere, HCl suppresses the decomposition of Н2О2, in hydrogen, on the contrary, the rate of Н2О2 conversion in the presence of HCl even increases (Table 2, lines 5–6, 8–9, 10–11). This fact allows us to assume that the hydrogenation and decomposition of Н2О2 occur at different active sites. Comparison of the activities of the modified and unmodified catalysts in Н2О2 “hydrogenation” in an acidic medium shows that the acidic inhibitor neutralizes the effect of phosphorus on the rate of side decomposition and hydrogenation of Н2О2 in hydrogen at a ratio of P:Pd = 0.3. However, Pd-P catalysts, even at low P:Pd ratios, are more efficient in synthesizing Н2О2 than Pd/ZSM-5. The higher productivity of Pd-P particles in the direct synthesis of H2O2 in the presence of an acidic inhibitor, as compared to unmodified Pd/ZSM-5 catalysts, indicates a significant promoting effect of phosphorus not only on the decomposition of H2O2, but also on the ratio of the rates of two parallel reactions: the formation of H2O2 or H2O from hydrogen and oxygen (Eqs. 1–2). The following factors can lead to the inhibition of H2O formation according to reaction (2) under the action of Pd-P catalysts. Earlier, using the example of Pd-P particles, XPS showed [27], that with an increase in the initial P:Pd ratio from 0.3 to 1.0, the surface concentration of oxidized phosphorus species in the form of phosphites and phosphates increases from 3.3 to 12.6 at%, and the ratio of surface [H2PO3 –+H2PO4 –]: [PdΣ] concentration increases from 0.45 to 3.2, respectively (Fig. A.25, SI). It turns out that the adsorption of phosphate ions not only suppresses the catalytic decomposition of H2O2 (Table 2). According to the reported data [48], phosphate ions adsorb on the Pd surface and inhibit O2 chemisorption. That is, they slow down the reaction (2). However, with an increase in the initial ratio P:Pd from 0.3 to 1.0, the Pd3d 5/2 binding energy and the Рδ–: PdΣ ratio also change. At the ratio P:Pd = 0.3, the Pd3d 5/2 binding energy is 334.5 eV (Pd0) and 336.3 eV (Pdδ+), and the ratio of surface concentrations Рδ–: PdΣ corresponds to 1: 20 [27] (Table A.2, SI). At the ratio P:Pd = 1, the binding energies of Pd0 (Eb(Pd3d 5/2) = 335.7 eV) and Pdδ+ (Eb(Pd3d 5/2) = 336.0 eV) exceed the binding energy in metallic Pd (Eb(Pd3d 5/2) = 335.2 eV), while the Рδ–: PdΣ ratio increases to 1: 3.5 [27] (Table A.2, SI). The predominance of electron-deficient forms of Pd on the surface of Pd-P particles (P:Pd = 1) should also impede the dissociation of O2, and, as a consequence, should also reduce the rate of water formation [44]. Besides, according to the reported experimental data [49], higher concentrations of H2O2 were achieved using nanoparticles in the form of an α-PdHx phase or a mixture of α- and β-PdHx phases, while an excess of hydrogen in the β-PdHx phase led to the formation of H2O instead of Н2О2. On the one hand, the formation of solid solutions between palladium and phosphorus reduces the solubility of hydrogen in Pd [46] and increases the rate of Н2О2 hydrogenation. On the other hand, it decreases the rate of the main side process, water formation from H2 and O2. 5 Conclusions Efficient catalysts for the direct synthesis of Н2О2 from hydrogen and oxygen have been developed. The activity of the catalysts (340 molН2О2(kgPd h))–1) under mild conditions exceeds the activity of many known analogs.The promoting effect of phosphorus on the dispersity of Pd catalysts, their activity, and selectivity in synthesizing Н2О2 is determined. A direct relationship between the P:Pd ratio (in the range P:Pd = 0 ÷ 1.0) and the activity of the catalysts is shown. A completely different effect of phosphorus on the properties of Pd catalysts in the side processes of Н2О2 decomposition and hydrogenation is found. It is assumed that the main cause of the selectivity increase with respect to Н2О2 is the formation of solid solutions between palladium and phosphorus. Dittmeyer, Effect of Selectivity Enhancers on the Structure of Palladium during High-Pressure Continuous-Flow Direct Synthesis of Hydrogen Peroxide in Ethanol, J. Phys. Chem. C. 125 (2021) 3451−3462. https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jpcc.0c11246

coredata.dc:description: The behavior of palladium-phosphorus catalysts deposited on a Na-ZSM-5 zeolite support, in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide under mild conditions has been studied. It was found that elemental phosphorus exerts a promoting effect on the activity and selectivity of Pd catalysts for synthesizing H2O2. A direct relationship between the P:Pd ratio (in the range P:Pd = 0: 1.0) and the activity of the catalysts is shown. The influence of phosphorus on the properties of palladium catalysts in side reactions: decomposition and hydrogenation of H2O2 is considered. The chemical and phase composition of Pd-P particles was studied by ICP, HRTEM, electron diffraction, and XRD methods. The modifying effect of phosphorus on the properties of Pd catalysts in the direct synthesis of H2O2 is associated with the formation of solid solutions between palladium and phosphorus, an increase in the dispersion, and the surface roughness of Pd-P particles.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of a phosphorus modifier on the behavior of palladium catalysts in direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide
